1.q_string: A buffer solution is prepared by mixing 'a' moles of \(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COONa}\) and ' \(\mathrm{b}\) ' moles of \(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COOH}\) such that \((a+b)=1\), into water to make \(1 \mathrm{~L}\) buffer solution. If the buffer capacity of this buffer solution is plotted against moles of salt \(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COONa}\) (with 'a') then the plot obtained will be (to the scale) approximatel:

q_option: At room temperature the solubility of \(\mathrm{KNO}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{KCl}\) are not equal.
The solubilities of both \(\mathrm{KNO}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{KCl}\) increase with temperature.
The solubility of \(\mathrm{KNO}_{3}\) increases much more compared to that of \(\mathrm{KCl}\) with increase in temperature.
1.q_string: Given the solubility curves of \(\mathrm{KNO}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{KCl}\), which of the following statements is not true?

Solid \(\mathrm{Ba}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}\) is gradually dissolved in a \(1.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaN}{ }_{2} \mathrm{CO}_{3}\) solution. At which concentration of \(\mathrm{Ba}^{2+}\), precipitate of \(\mathrm{BaCO}_{3}\) begins to form? (Given \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{sp}}\) for \(\left.\mathrm{BaCO}_{3}=5.1 \times 10^{-9}\right) \text { }\)

\(50 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(0.6 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaOH}\) is added to \(100 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(0.6 \mathrm{M}\) acetic acid. What is the additional volume of \(1.2 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaOH}\) required for making the solution of \(\mathrm{pH}\) value \(4.74\)? The ionization constant of acetic acid is \(1.8 \times 10^{-5}\).

Given that at \(800 \mathrm{k}\) the concentrations are as follows:

\(\mathrm{N}_{2}=3.0 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}, \mathrm{O}_{2}=4.2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}\) and \(\mathrm{NO}=2.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}\) , what is the equilibrium constant for the reaction \(\mathrm{N}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+\mathrm{O}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}(\mathrm{g}) ?\)

At equilibrium, \(500 \mathrm{ml}\) vessel contains \(1.5 \mathrm{M}\) of each \(A, B, C, D\) if \(0.5 \mathrm{M}\) of \(C\) and \(D\) expelled out then what would be the \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{c}}\)? The reaction at equilibrium is \(A+B \rightarrow C+D\).
If the concentrations of two weak acids are different and degrees of ionisation \((\alpha)\) are very less, then their relative strengths can be compared by:

The \(\mathrm{pH}\) of a solution obtained by mixing \(100 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(0.2 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COOH}\) with \(100 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(0.2 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaOH}\) would be (Given that: \(\left.\mathrm{pK}_{\mathrm{a}}=4.74\right)\)
For the reaction, \(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+\mathrm{I}_{2}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{HI}(\mathrm{g})\), the equilibrium constant \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{p}}\) changes with:

q_option: The molecules dissolved in the liquid without pressure
The molecules in the gaseous state and the molecules dissolved in the liquid under pressure
The molecules in the solid state and the molecules dissolved in the liquid under pressure

The dissociation of water at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is \(1.9 \times 10^{-7} \%\) and the density of water is \(1.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cc}\). The ionisation constant of water is:

q_option: Autoprotolysis constant of water increases with temperature
When a solution of weak monoprotic acid is titrated against a strong base, at half neutralization point \(\mathrm{pH}=\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{pKa}\)
1.q_string: Which of the following statements is correct?

The first and second dissociation constants of an acid \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{~A}\) are \(1.0 \times 10^{-5}\) and \(5.0 \times 10^{-10}\) respectively. The overall dissociation constant of the acid will be:

The dissociation constants of a weak acid \(\mathrm{HA}\) and weak base \(\mathrm{BOH}\) are \(2 \times 10^{-5}\) and \(5 \times 10^{-6}\) respectively. The equilibrium constant for the neutralisation reaction of the two is:
